School of Environmental Science and Engineering Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Buildings and heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems are appropriate resources for demand response, but there is still a lack of rapid quantification methods to reveal buildings’ dynamic demand response potential under different meteorological conditions and control strategies. In order to achieve real-time power grid dispatch and to facilitate grid-building interaction, this paper proposes a framework for establishing models to rapidly quantify the demand response potential of resources. First, a detailed co-simulation model of the building and its energy system is constructed, followed by extensive stochastic simulations of two commonly used demand response strategies, after which the demand response potential is quantified using a set of indices. Then, feature selection is performed on factors that may affect demand response potential, and a data-driven model for quantifying demand response potential is proposed, whose results are compared with those from the simulation model. Also, the demand response effects of the two control strategies are compared in this paper. A case study was carried out in an industrial building in Shenzhen, China. The results showed that under different boundaries, the coefficient of determination ( R 2 ) of the quantification indices are all above 0.9, and that the data-driven model rapidly and accurately captured the demand response potential of the building and its heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system, and was easy to deploy in practice. Keywords Demand response potential Flexibility Data-driven model Modelica Building energy systems Data availability Post-processed data for building machine learning models, (Original data) 1 Introduction 1.1 Background and literature review As the population grows and industrialization accelerates, the peak electricity demand is increasing day by day. At the same time, with the strengthening global consensus on carbon reduction, the penetration of renewable energy in power generation will further increase. In 2030, China's installed power generation capacity of renewable energy will account for 40 %. The increase in peak demand and the renewable energy penetration further brings challenges to stabilize the power grid [1]. As a result, while the infrastructure investment on the power supply side is high, changes on the demand side are more urgent to be made, which is conducive to reducing power generation capacity, avoiding congestion on the transmission and distribution network, and saving costs. Therefore, the flexibility at the energy demand side is receiving more and more attention [2,3]. Building energy consumption accounts for one-third of global energy consumption, while heating, ventilation and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems consume more than 50 % of the building energy [4,5]. Building load can be reduced by passive thermal storage or HVAC system regulation without doing much harm to the thermal comfort, as a result, buildings can be taken as good flexibility resources [6,7].In the IEA report, it is pointed out that in 2018, the building demand response potential (DRP) reached 3071TWh, accounting for 77.4 % of the total value, and by 2050, the available flexible resources of the residential, commercial, and industrial sectors will be ten times more than they were in 2019. However, the report also illustrated that less than 2 % of the current DRP was efficiently utilized in 2019 [8].To improve this, it is necessary to identify the available demand response (DR) resources in the building and their ability to provide services to the grid, to achieve real-time power grid dispatch [9]. Therefore, how to rapidly quantify the DRP of the building has become an urgent problem at present. Related works in 5 years are listed in Table 1 . The first step for quantifying DRP is to determine indices that cater to the needs of the power grid. One way is to use differential electrical power before and after the DR to represent the flexibility of different resources. However, a single index sometimes fails to reveal the difference among various regulating measures [6,10]. Refs. [11–13] proposed a set of indices including power shifting capability, available storage capacity, thermal storage loss, and thermal storage efficiency during the DR event, and energy loss during the DR recovery stage. They also proposed a general flexibility quantification framework that is applicable to systems with multiple flexibility resources and intends to describe the capacity of flexibility resources and their utilization efficiency. In Refs. [14–16], indices such as response time, recovery time, and ramp rate were further considered, because of the different dynamic characteristics of different types of resources. For example, chillers can respond within a few minutes [17], fans usually complete load shedding within 15 min [18,19], lighting response time is 30 ∼ 40 s, and pre-cooling of the building thermal mass and utilization of energy storage require several hours in advance [20,21]. In other words, in addition to the capacity of flexibility resources, the response speed also needs to be considered. In Refs. [22,23], a more detailed set of indices was used to describe the DR process, including the time, power, and capacity in each phase. Compared to the aforementioned studies, indices in [22,23] can directly interact with the grid and is more similar to the grid flexibility indices, and the efficiency and capacity of the flexibility resources on the demand side are less concerned [24]. It can be seen that, in order to meet the needs of power dispatching, the DRP of each flexible resource needs to be characterized by multiple indices. After selecting an appropriate set of indices, it is also necessary to consider how to obtain the potential of these resources, and how to quickly quantify the potential when the dispatched command is given by the grid. Methods used in the existing research on building flexibility quantification include field experiments, simulation-based and data-driven methods. Li et al. [25] reduced the peak power consumption by 16.74 % through equipment on–off control. When the thermal inertia of the air conditioning system was considered, the power was further reduced by 1.93 % by adjusting the chilled water temperature. Field experiments can reflect the real DRP of various resources in buildings. Still, it is difficult to quantify the flexibility of the building under all working conditions, and to explore the general rules, due to large human and time costs. So far, most of the research is still based on simulation: establishing system models through simulation software such as EnergyPlus[26], TRNSYS[27], Dymola/Modelica[28], etc., or using reduced-order models (RC), to simulate the thermal dynamics of buildings and implement various DR strategies. Chen et al.[10] explored the DRP of different resources in the building, and the results showed that the DRP of the building thermal mass accounted for more than 70 %. Finck et al.[11] studied the influence of thermal energy storage (TES) on the DRP of the system through the optimal control of the TES charge/discharge rate. The results showed that with TES the flexibility of the system was greatly improved, and the DR services were provided during different stages. Arteconi et al.[15] studied the influence of climate, and the thermal inertia of building thermal mass and HVAC on DRP, and did sensitivity analysis; the results also showed that systems with high thermal inertia had a positive effect on enhancing DRP. Yin et al. [29] determined the optimal pre-cooling strategy based on the calibrated simulation model, and by adjusting the indoor temperature setpoint, it was shown in field tests that the peak power demand was reduced by 15–30 %. Furthermore, advanced control strategies such as Model Predictive Control (MPC) were employed in some studies to extract the maximum available DRP, especially in systems with energy storage devices, which can capture the temporal DRP changes of buildings through optimal scheduling[11,30,31]. Amadeh et al.[32] further considered the impact of model uncertainty and weather forecast uncertainty[33] on DRP quantification within the MPC framework. However, this requires MPC to be applied in practice to reach its full potential, while MPC has not yet been commonly used in the field; and meanwhile, time for calculation is not easy to control. A few studies further incorporated data-driven approaches, where simulation models were used to test algorithms or expand datasets. Luo et al.[34] constructed a Bayesian network to extract the DRP of HVAC, lighting, and plug loads from the simulation results. Yu et al.[35] estimated the DRP on an urban scale based on the historical data acquired from previous DR events of buildings, using building characteristics and DR information, etc. as features through the XGboost model. The benefit of data-driven approaches is that data-driven models can learn from the quantification results of simulation models, thereby speeding up computations by replacing white-box models. In addition, it’s easier to embed less complicated computational procedures in practical systems. To conclude, there are still issues that have not been stressed in related works: first, in some cases, the DRP is gained in static external boundaries or fixed DR durations, where it’s impossible to quantify DRP at any given time; additionally, physical simulation modeling is still the most commonly used method for DRP quantification, which is faced with burden in computation and limitation in the platform; furthermore, some indices are not sufficient to reveal the features of DR resources, while some are not entirely geared to the grid operators. 2 Research targets To solve the above issues and facilitate the interaction between buildings and the grids, a framework is proposed to establish data-driven models to quantify DRP rapidly. The data-driven model can reflect the DRP by multiple indices under different operation conditions and DR strategies. Also, the input variables for the data-driven model are accessible from the measured data of most building energy management systems (BEMS). Compared to simulation models, it is faster in computation speed, easier to be integrated into BEMS, and can be used in real-time power grid dispatch. This paper is organized as below: in section 2, the overall technical framework for generating a rapid DRP quantification model is described. In section 2.1, the simulation tools and methods to generate DR data are introduced; section 2.2 illustrates the process of generating training data set, and describes the DR scenarios used for quantification and their corresponding evaluation indices; section 2.3 describes the process of establishing a data-driven model using a simulation model. In section 3, the feasibility of the above method is verified through a case study, and the results of the feature selection and DRP estimation model in different scenarios are given. At the end of section 3, the generalization ability of the estimation model is verified by simulating scenarios outside of the training set. Section 4 is the conclusion part, and the limitations of the research are also pointed out. 3 Method This paper proposes a method for rapidly quantifying the DRP of building air-conditioning systems. The outline of the method is shown in Fig. 1 . It is difficult to obtain a DR dataset under all working conditions in practice. For this reason, this paper firstly builds a twin model of the actual system to generate DR data under rich working conditions and to reflect the dynamic characteristics of each part of the actual system in detail through co-simulation. Moreover, as mentioned in section 1, there’re various DR strategies for air-conditioning systems; thus, the DRP quantification method in this paper is intended to be applicable to different strategies. As an example, the DRP of two commonly used DR strategies (indoor temperature setpoint resetting and equipment on–off control) are quantified in this paper under abundant scenarios of different climate and working conditions, as shown in Step 2. In Step 3, a rapid DRP quantification model is built for the above two strategies via a data-driven approach. To improve the accuracy of quantification, feature selection and determination of hyper-parameters for data-driven models are required, which is briefly described in section 2.3. In the last step, to further verify the generalization ability of the DRP quantification model, random simulation was employed to obtain verification data, and the estimation accuracy of the model was validated. 3.1 System modeling It is difficult to obtain sufficient training datasets in actual systems. Therefore, a simulation model of the physical system was established to generate DR data under different operating conditions and different regulating measures. This paper took the building’s air-conditioning system as the research object. The flexibility is affected by two parts: the thermal inertia of the building, and the coupling dynamic characteristics of the thermal, hydraulic and control system of the HVAC[37]. However, a single simulation tool is not able to reflect the dynamics of both thermal mass and HVAC in detail at the same time, which can be complemented by co-simulation[38]. EnergyPlus is widely used in building load simulation, and in this paper, it was applied to simulate the building envelope, as shown in Fig. 2 , where parameters in black represent inputs, and those in red represent interactive variables of the co-simulation. Scenarios with different loads and those with random internal disturbance were generated respectively by typical annual meteorological data and Monte Carlo simulation. It was assumed that in this case, an industrial building, the internal disturbance was relatively stable, whose schedule was generated by the superposition of three random signals: firstly, a benchmark of random internal disturbance ranging from 0.4 ∼ 1(per day) to describe the impact of the number of factory orders; and then two noise values with sampling time of 1 h and 10 min respectively ranging −0.2 ∼ 0.2 and −0.05 ∼ 0.05 to express the short-term fluctuation of the internal disturbance. The schedule was generated through the Advanced Noise library[39]. EnergyPlus can accurately simulate the thermal dynamic characteristics of buildings, but its modeling ability for HVAC systems is limited, and its control system model is often ideal, and with a fixed simulation step size through which the short-time dynamic features cannot be captured[40]. Thus, an equation-based and object-oriented language Modelica that can couple thermal, hydraulic, and control systems with variable step size [41] was employed. The advantages of Modelica for HVAC simulation are explained in detail in the literature [42,43]. The Buildings library [44] was used to build the component model of the energy and control system, and the State graph library [45] was used to model the discrete control sequences like on–off control of the equipment. A primary pump constant flow system was constructed, as shown in Fig. 3 , including two chillers (one of which as a back-up unit), as well as two pumps and two cooling towers; the terminal is a primary air fan-coil system. The frequency of chillers was controlled by the chilled water outlet temperature, while the water pumps and cooling towers were operated at a fixed frequency; the opening ratio of the bypass valve was controlled by the differential pressure of the main pipe supply and return water; the opening ratio of the water valve of the fan coil was controlled by the air supply temperature; the speed of fans was controlled by the indoor temperature which was to be maintained at 25 °C. The model paths are shown in Table 2 . Since the building and HVAC system were modeled on different simulation platforms, Functional Mock-up Interface (FMI)[50] was used to couple the two. The sensible and latent heat of the building was calculated by Modelica, and exported to EnergyPlus where the building indoor average temperature and humidity were calculated. The communication step of the co-simulation was 60 s[38]. The system model in Modelica is shown in Fig. 4 . 3.2 DR control strategies and evaluation indices DR potential of the system under different conditions can be obtained via extensive simulations based on various control strategies. In this paper, results of simulations without DR were defined as the benchmark, and two commonly used DR strategies were selected, which are simple enough to be executed by the BEMS of many buildings in practice. In this section, the indices and the datasets generation process are described, aiming to generate a sufficient training dataset for the rapid DRP quantification model. 3.2.1 DR strategies • Global Temperature Adjusting (Strategy A)[18,51]: raising the indoor temperature setpoint ( T indoor , s p ) of all fan coils at the beginning of DR, to reduce cooling load and thus reduce system power. The fluctuation of indoor temperature and power of the HVAC system during the DR are shown in Fig. 5 : Stage 1:at the beginning of DR, due to the increase of the indoor temperature setpoint, the load of fans falls quickly within 5 ∼ 20 min, causing the part load ratio of chillers to drop rapidly, and the maximum power shedding is thus obtained. Stage 2:as the indoor temperature continuously increases during the DR, and the speed of fans gradually increases to maintain the indoor temperature at the new setpoint. During this stage, the power of the system is relatively stable but still lower than that in the benchmark case. Stage 3:when DR is terminated, and indoor temperature setpoint is restored to its original value, the speed of fans climbs, causing a rebound of power till the indoor temperature drops to the setpoint. • Shut Down Chiller Plant Equipment (strategy B)[17,52]: turning off all equipment in the chiller plant (including chillers, chilled water pumps, cooling water pumps and cooling towers) at the beginning of DR, while the air conditioning terminal equipment still keeps running. The fluctuation of indoor temperature and power of the HVAC system during the DR are shown in Fig. 6 : Stage 1:At the beginning of DR, devices of HVAC are shut down sequentially within a few minutes according to the preset control sequence, and then the power of the system falls discretely, after which the maximum power shedding is reached. Due to the shortage of cooling supply, the indoor temperature starts to rise after a short delay, and consequently the speed of fans increases rapidly to its maximum. Stage 2:As cooling demand cannot be satisfied, and the indoor temperature continuously rises up to its upper limit. Stage3:DR is forced to terminate because of the indoor temperature limit, and all devices are turned on. At this moment an intensive power rebound occurs due to high cooling demand and high return chilled water temperature, until the indoor temperature becomes relatively stable. To be clear: first, for strategy A, the load shedding speed of fans is related to the difference of indoor temperature and its setpoint; for strategy B, the load shedding speed is mainly linked to the on–off control sequence of devices, and thus the duration from the beginning of DR to the maximum power shedding point is not quantified. Second, the duration of DR in strategy A is controllable, while that in strategy B is determined by the upper limit of the indoor temperature ( T indoor , l i m ), which means that when the indoor temperature reaches the upper limit, the DR process is forced to terminate, or else the temperature will continue to increase; as a result, the duration of DR in strategy A is taken as the input that affects DRP, and that in strategy B is the output of the quantification results. 3.2.2 DR evaluation indices In this paper, the dynamic indices were selected to quantify the DR process, from two perspectives: time and power [16],which are similar to the flexibility indices of the grid so that they can be directly used by the grid without any further conversion. In many studies, the surrogate model is a date-driven model[53], and in this section, methods for establishing data-driven models to rapidly quantify DRP is introduced: firstly, a machine learning model was defined, then input variables that may affect the model were manually selected, based on which feature engineering and hyper-parameters optimization were performed to obtain optimum DRP quantification model. 5.2 The machine learning model The machine learning model constructed in this paper is to rapidly obtain the flexibility of buildings quantified by indices in section 2.2.2 under certain boundary conditions and DR control strategies. The quantification results were the targets of machine learning, and to obtain the most suitable features and the most accurate results, data-driven models were established for each one of the indices. Multi-layer Perceptron (MLP) is a commonly used supervised machine learning method, which uses multiple neurons in multiple layers to mimic the human brain, and it has been pointed out[54,55] that MLP can be used to model and control buildings and their energy systems, and can accurately approximate the nonlinear system dynamics. It has one input layer, one or more hidden layers (HL), and one output layer, and it’s a simple feed-forward network whose output signal is completely calculated based on the current input signal. In this paper, an MLP network model with 2 hidden layers was constructed, the l-BFGS algorithm was used to train the model[56],and the mean absolute error (MAE) was employed as the scoring criterion of the model, as shown in formula (2). If variables need to be predicted, their acquisition should not be too complex. Feature variables to be selected are shown in Table 4 , there were 20 variables for strategy A and 19 for strategy. Among the variables in the table, the cooling load ( CL ) was calculated from the differential temperature and flow rate of the supply and return chilled water which are easy to obtain with sensors in the building, and also, load prediction algorithms based on these variables are also mature; outdoor temperature ( T odb ) and relative humidity ( RH ) were obtained directly through meteorological platforms. Other variables such as internal disturbances, system internal state, and irradiance were not selected, either because the state estimation is required for these variables, or because sensors for monitoring such variables are expensive and unavailable in most buildings. 5.4 Feature engineering and hyper-parameters tuning In this section, all the data described in 2.2.3 will be used, the process of selecting the most reasonable features and hyper-parameters for the above MLP is introduced, as shown in Fig. 7 , to improve the accuracy of DRP quantification. Commonly used feature selection methods include: filtering, wrapping, and embedding[57]. Among these methods, the filtering method has the advantage of fast calculation, but it is only performed from the data level, and the selection result is independent of the model and is uncertain [53]; the selection result of the embedding method is affected by the parameters of the machine learning model itself. The threshold of both the filtering and embedding method needs to be determined subjectively. The wrapping method, on the contrary, is tailored for the model, through which better selection results can be obtained. However, due to the need to traverse the feature sets, the computation requirements are higher than the first two methods, especially when the amount of data and features are large. The number of feature variables selected in this paper was less than 20, and the calculation burden of the wrapping method and cross-validation[58] was within an acceptable range. Sequential Feature Selection (SFS) is commonly used in the wrapping method, which is a greedy process that starts with an empty set and fills it with selected optimal new features based on the cross-validation score in each iteration, and this process is repeated until the desired number of selected features is reached[57]. Since this method is model-based, if MLP is used as the benchmark model, the computation time will be long, and the hyperparameters will not be determined. Consequently, in this paper a compromise method that built a two-layer loop was employed to obtain the most suitable features and models. First, the LassoCV model[59] was used to rapidly and recursively preselect features even if it was different from the MLP model, and then the model was trained based on the selected features, and the MLP hyperparameters were tuned. The detailed process is as follows: • Date-preprocessing: features were standardized by removing the mean and scaling to unit variance. • In loop A, LassoCV was used as an estimator to select the optimum feature among i features by recursing forward, and meanwhile, 10 folds cross-validation (cv = 10) was performed to improve the generalization ability. • In loop B, i variables with the highest score were used as the input of the model, and the MLP model was initialized, and then the Bayesian algorithm was used to optimize the number of neurons in each layer (maximum 50 neurons per layer), and 10 folds cross-validation was also performed. • The loop was ended until i was equal to the number of variables in the feature set, and the scores under different features were output. 5.5 Toolchain In this paper, Dymola was used as the solver and compiler of Modelica, and EnergyPlus was used for modeling the building, and the two were coupled through FMI. A co-simulation platform of EnergyPlus and Modelica was established to simulate the system dynamics when a demand response event occurs, and the potential of two commonly used demand response strategies were quantified via a set of indices from both time and power perspectives. Afterward, a large number of stochastic simulations were carried out to generate the training dataset, and the Multi-layer Perceptron was used to establish the relationship between the demand response potential and the different boundary conditions. Finally, feature engineering and hyper-parameter tuning are used to tailor the model for each quantification index to obtain the highest accuracy. The primary conclusions of the study as follows: 1. Demand response potential was quantified by multiple indices under different control strategies. Compared to global temperature adjusting, shutting down the equipment led to greater power shedding, with shorter durations and more power rebound. At the same time, these indices’ values vary under different meteorological boundaries, cooling loads, and control parameters. Therefore, users needed to consider the impact of these factors to meet various demand response programs. 2. The data-driven model was able to replace the physical simulation model to accurately quantify the demand response potential with good generalization capability. When global temperature adjustment was applied, the coefficients of determination in training and validation were above 0.94 and 0.92, respectively; and when shutting down the equipment, that in training and validation were above 0.98 and 0.96, respectively. 3. The computation of Multi-layer Perceptron was faster than physical simulation models, thus facilitating real-time interaction between the building and the power grid. Future work will include further evaluation of demand response potential for different building types and combinations of multiple strategies, in addition to examining the impact of load forecast errors on the accuracy of demand response potential quantification, and capturing the demand response potential of buildings with fewer data. coredata.dc:description: Buildings and heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems are appropriate resources for demand response, but there is still a lack of rapid quantification methods to reveal buildings’ dynamic demand response potential under different meteorological conditions and control strategies. In order to achieve real-time power grid dispatch and to facilitate grid-building interaction, this paper proposes a framework for establishing models to rapidly quantify the demand response potential of resources. First, a detailed co-simulation model of the building and its energy system is constructed, followed by extensive stochastic simulations of two commonly used demand response strategies, after which the demand response potential is quantified using a set of indices. Then, feature selection is performed on factors that may affect demand response potential, and a data-driven model for quantifying demand response potential is proposed, whose results are compared with those from the simulation model. Also, the demand response effects of the two control strategies are compared in this paper. A case study was carried out in an industrial building in Shenzhen, China. The results showed that under different boundaries, the coefficient of determination ( R 2 ) of the quantification indices are all above 0.9, and that the data-driven model rapidly and accurately captured the demand response potential of the building and its heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system, and was easy to deploy in practice.
